awd_titl_txt: CAREER: A Framework for Revealing How Locomotor Control Emerges from the reciprocal Interactions of Neural and Mechanical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Animals move with remarkable stability and agility through nearly every environment. To do so, they rely on interacting neural and mechanical systems that must operate in the context of the physics of sensing, actuation, and environmental interactions. Modern data acquisition tools provide unprecedented access to the underlying neural, muscular, and mechanical signals that implement control. However, these signals alone are not a framework for understanding how sensory information transforms into motor outputs. This CAREER project leverages several emerging experimental and analytical techniques to show how locomotor dynamics emerge from this sensorimotor transform. This framework for extracting principles of sensorimotor control is based on combining high-resolution neuromuscular recordings, information theoretic and dimensionality-reduction data analytics, and the formal language of system identification and control theory. The experimental framework of this proposal is transferrable to other living and engineered systems composed of many subsystems connected by feedback such as gene or protein networks, cell mechanics, or population dynamics. Principles of locomotor control that emerge from this work will synergize with the BRAIN initiative and similar programs by providing context through which to interpret a deep, detailed understanding of brain structure, anatomy, and connectivity. They will also address challenges in the new era of robotics and neural engineering. There is a pressing need for neuro-technologies that enable versatile movement while embodied in physical systems. More broadly this work will enable translation of research-based undergraduate learning into scientific and education products. It will bring a neuroscience component to the growing Physics of Living Systems curriculum at Georgia Tech. Within the VIP program, students will receive training at the interface of biology, physics, and engineering by engaging in research-based learning that is organized into a vertical mentoring system. Ultimately the study of how brain and body control movement is an accessible context in which to engage the public and further converge education of physics and biology even outside the walls of the research university.

The research uses three experimental platforms (two animals and one robot). They provide insights into the shared neural and mechanical processing challenges animals face despite using different modes of locomotion. The research program includes recording and altering a nearly complete motor program (the set of all neuromuscular commands to appendages) with spike-level resolution while an animal behaves in a virtual reality environment. The PI's work also explores the performance consequences of different control architectures and the sensorimotor determinants on maneuverability. The program will use the interdisciplinary study of movement to create a scientific foundry for the Physics of Living Systems at Georgia Tech with an emphasis on how physics approaches provide a context for understanding neural signals. The core of the foundry will be a vertically integrated research team of undergraduates that will complete the loop of research-based education to classroom-inspired research. To transfer the impact outside the university, the researchers will team with local high school teachers to innovate new education tools based on the accessibility of high-speed imaging, surface electromyography, and the study of movement.

por.por_cntn:
During locomotion, animals must process sensory information and transform it into motor output, which requires coordination between the nervous system, sensors, and actuators. However, understanding how the sensorimotor transform controls movement remains challenging due to parallel signals, evolved control systems, and difficulties in translating experimental results between neuroscience and biomechanics. At the same timing it is challenging to train the next generation of leaders in the interface of scientific fields that touch on the science of movement.

 

The four aims of this work were to:

1)    Test the degree of centralization that an occurs between the many muscles, limbs, and components of both animals and robots as they move through different contexts.

2)    Test how a comprehensive and high-resolution motor program ? the set of all neuromuscular signals an animal uses to control agile movement ? coordinates and controls movement.

3)    Test how simple behavioral dynamics emerge from the interaction of sensory and motor systems using the formalisms of control theory to explore how agile flying insects adapt their flight control to different conditions.

4)    Develop a scientific foundary for education in neuromechanics.

 

In Aim 1 we develop a model-free measure to determine the level of centralization in a system using information theory. We showed that this measure could capture the degree of centralization in animals, robots, and computer simulations and developed a new design space. We also developed a second measure to assess the degree of redundancy in control. We then focused on studying cockroaches, which are agile runners and perform better than engineered systems in terms of movement. Our results show that cockroaches adopt a more centralized control system to maintain stability in faster and more uncertain conditions. The stronger mechanical connections between different parts of the body could simplify control systems and reduce computational requirements in both organisms and robots.

 

In Aim 2 we develop a use a robotic flower arena to probe how the brains of agile flying hawkmoths can combine multiple streams of sensory information and adapt to exceptionally low light levels. We discovered that they slow their brains down to better collect light over longer periods of time, but only to the point where they can still keep up with the movements of the flowers the naturally feed from. Across species, these visual adaptations adjust based on whether the species is a nighttime or daytime flier. These results show an exquisite matching of neuromechanical control to ecology. Beyond vision we discovered that they use tactile sensations from touching the flower in conjunction with their visual sense and adjust both senses to compensate for flying at night. Together these results give new insights into how simple biophysical dynamics emerge from the interaction of the brain and the body even during challenging behaviors like flight.

 

In Aim 3, we achieved simultaneous recording of nearly all the electrical impulses the moths brain sends to its wings during flight. We could resolve every action potential, the discrete spikes of electrical activity in the brain. Muscles are usually thought to encode movement in the average rate of these spikes of activation. We found that despite being fast, the moth did have sufficient bandwidth to control its behavior with rates codes. However, it predominantly relied on timing codes, specifying most of its motor control down to the millisecond scale. Moreover, they coordinated their muscle exclusively in timing. This shows that motor control of agile behaviors is much more like an orchestra, with each muscle having its own rate control, but the music or movement coming from the brain conducting the precisely timed interplay of multiple muscles.

 

In Aim 4, we developed an upper-division and graduate neurophysics course that combines advance physics coursework with hands-on electrophysiology, cardiac, and behavior labs. We hosted a local GK-12 teacher and administrator developing curriculum for a new charter school to expand access to STEM. Finally, and perhaps most significantly we adapted the vertically integrated project (VIP) model from engineering to the sciences to create the living dynamical systems VIP team. The team ran for 7 semesters (with a pause due to the pandemic) and integrates authentic research experiences into the undergraduate major curriculum. This breaks down barriers to participation in research experience. The VIP team is ongoing but has already trained >65 students and resulted in two publications, each with ~10 student authors that appeared in top international journals (Proceedings of the Royal Society B and Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences).

 

Overall, the grant supported in part or in whole the training of 8 graduate students, 3 postdocs, 4 research technicians and 10 undergraduate students directly in the lab, 1 summer K-12 teacher fellow, and >65 undergraduates participating through the VIP program. The grant led to 25 publications, some collaborative, and over 40 presentations at conferences, workshops and seminars.
